column4: how do I change the screens that show while Ubuntu is booting?
there are plymouth themes in the repo, theres a deb for the ubuntu sunrise theme on gnome-loog.org
http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2010/09/ubuntu-sunrise-plymouth-theme-adds-awe-to-boot-time/
I am missing something here - on the URL that you sent me I do not see how to set my own at all
there is a link to gnome-look where there is a deb to install the splash
- ty so much the link that you gave me did give me how to make my own screens, or at least guided me enough that I worked it out
sweet :0
it'd have been smarter to test the ISO first. a bad ISO will make a bad CD
what speed do you burn at?
earlier today you asked me to do a pasetbin on the problem with the apt-get fialing - then u were gone - here is the URL http://pastebin.com/0gzKkdN9
wow you got a lot of spare kernels dude
https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux/+bug/589356
seems to be an issue with that kernel
I recommend you remove some of the old kernels too, taking up unecessary space
how do I remove them?

use software centre, same as any other package. Just do NOT remove the current kernel. If you run:  uname -r    you can see the kernel you are running. You can remove the older kernels and get ~120Mb per kernel in free space :)
sorry to be so dense but I do not see how to do that with the software center - is there anyway to do it at the shell anyway
gimme a sec I'll make you a command. What is the output of: uname -r
uname -r made 2.6.32-33-generic
http://pastebin.com/YcqAwzc7
the text file shown is the before and after space usage
I ran your command - it ran beautifully did not seem to help though - 42% useage - what now
I should add that the file shows same 42% both before and after
